newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU survey sees end of economic downturn.
newsitem.headline: EU survey sees end of economic downturn.

text.p: The European Commission said on Tuesday that confidence indicators pointed to an end to the economic slowdown which has been affecting the European Union since the end of 1995.

"Judging by the business survey results extending into August, there are now clearer signs that the pause in growth is coming to an end," it said in its survey of economic sentiment for August/September.
The Commission said confidence in industry had picked up in August, as the number of firms planning to increase production over the following months outnumbered those willing to reduce output.
But it tempered its assessment saying that domestic and foreign demand remained "far too low" and the level of stocks "excessive".
Consumer confidence also suggested a "slight improvement" in August mainly because people throughout the Union are "less pessimistic" about their own financial situation, the Commission said.
The Commission's somewhat brighter economic prospects for the bloc's economy are in line with its forecasts in May.
It said last spring that growth in gross domestic product would be 1.5 percent in 1996, down from a previous forecast of 2.6 percent.
The Commission blamed in particular the delayed effects of last year's monetary turbulence and the high level of interest rates in 1994 and 1995 for the bloc's economic downturn.
But it said the economy would recover during the second half of 1996 to reach 2.5 percent growth next year.
The Commission's regular autumn economic forecasts are expected by mid-November.
